articles.content:
Meet 13 People Who Survived on Deserted Islands, From a Real-Life Robinson Crusoe to a Noblewoman Marooned With Her Lover
Ahead of the release of Sam Raimi’s “Send Help,” revisit the stories of Alexander Selkirk, Marguerite de la Rocque, the Tongan castaways and others who endured in remote locales
Countless books, movies and television shows chronicle the adventures (or misadventures) of people stranded on remote islands.
Consider, for example, Daniel Defoe’s Robinson Crusoe, the beloved Tom Hanks movie Cast Away and the classic 1960s sitcom “Gilligan’s Island.” Now Send Help, a new Sam Raimi horror-thriller about a woman (played by Rachel McAdams) stuck with her overbearing boss (Dylan O’Brien) after a plane crash, is set to join the ranks of these survivalist stories.
Narratives about deserted islands often depict the ingenuity required to build shelter and acquire food and water, as well as the mental fortitude needed to patiently wait for rescue. Many of these story lines are exaggerated and sensationalized for dramatic effect. Still, the challenge of being pitted against nature, secluded from civilization and forced to live with only the barest essentials taps into themes of resilience and adventure that have always fascinated humans.
When real-life stories of people somehow surviving on uninhabited islands emerge, the castaways quickly become celebrities. The public wants to know every detail of their experience—especially what it took for them to endure not just a handful of days but sometimes months, years or even decades of isolation. To mark Send Help’s release on January 30, read seven stories of people who found themselves stuck on remote islands and learn how they survived long enough to be rescued.
Alexander Selkirk
It’s only fitting to start with Scotsman Alexander Selkirk, whose tale of being marooned for four years and four months on Más a Tierra, an island 416 miles off the coast of the Chilean mainland, is widely cited as an inspiration for Defoe’s 1719 novel, Robinson Crusoe.
Born in the fishing village of Fife in 1676, Selkirk reportedly attracted the ire of local church authorities for assaulting his father, his brother and his sister-in-law. Afterward, he decided to leave home, finding work on various ships. One of the vessels was the Cinque Ports, which Selkirk believed was unfit to sail. Upon arriving on Más a Tierra, one of three landmasses that make up the Juan Fernández Islands, in 1704, he boldly proclaimed that he’d rather stay behind than get back onto the leaky ship. Expecting the other sailors to make the same declaration, Selkirk was shocked when the Cinque Ports proceeded to sail off without him.
“The ship itself was in poor condition, and he believed it would sink, which indeed it did,” Andrew Lambert, a naval historian at King’s College London, told National Geographic in 2016. “So his basis for putting himself ashore was quite sound. The ship sank, and half the crew drowned.”
Initially, Selkirk eked out a living with only a musket, a hatchet, a knife, a Bible, a cooking pot, bedding and some clothing left behind by the crew. After mating sea lions on the shore forced him inland, he survived by milking and butchering goats, whose skin he turned into clothing. He also found wild turnips, plants and fruits to supplement his diet.
Selkirk was rescued by an English vessel called the Duke in 1709. Its captain later noted that while the castaway was overjoyed to be saved, his outlook suggested that perhaps “solitude and retirement from the world is not such an unsufferable state of life as most men imagine.” Selkirk’s experiences, the captain argued, “may likewise instruct us how much a plain and temperate way of living conduces to the health of the body and the vigor of the mind, both which we are apt to destroy by excess and plenty.”
When Selkirk returned to England in 1711, he attracted a great deal of media attention. He eventually sailed to West Africa in hopes of fighting pirates but soon caught a disease, likely yellow fever or typhoid, and died on December 13, 1721.
Fernão Lopes
Arguably no one on this list was left on their deserted island in a worse state than Fernão Lopes. A Portuguese soldier, Lopes sailed with his compatriots to India in 1510 and participated in the capture of the port of Goa. Lopes reportedly rode into Goa with Afonso de Albuquerque, the governor of Portuguese India, following a priest who carried a cross and the banner of the Order of Christ. The procession signaled Portugal’s ambition to convert India’s Hindus and Muslims into Christians.
Lopes, however, did exactly the opposite, converting from Christianity to Islam alongside several of his fellow soldiers. When Albuquerque discovered this betrayal, he chopped off the men’s noses, ears, tongues, right hands and left thumbs as punishment. Lopes survived this torture and spent the next several years living in disgrace. It was only in 1516, after Albuquerque’s death, that he received a royal pardon and permission to return to Portugal. On the way back home, however, Lopes got off the ship at St. Helena (an uninhabited island 1,210 miles off Africa’s west coast) rather than face the reality of being viewed as a traitor in his home country.
According to The Other Exile, a 2017 biography of Lopes by author A.R. Azzam, St. Helena was home to a “highly nutritious” selection of edible plants and herbs. The island’s “shallows also boasted the reclusive but flamboyant angelfish and hundreds of butterfly and goat fish,” Azzam wrote. “Fresh water was everywhere, with streams gushing thanks to the almost daily rain.”
Lopes remained on St. Helena—the same island where Napoleon Bonaparte would die in exile in 1821—for about 14 years. He eventually returned to Portugal, where he met the king and queen. But the trip was brief, as Lopes was eager to return to St. Helena. He soon made his way back there, this time taking along pigs, chickens and goats. He died on the island in 1545.
Marguerite de la Rocque
The story of Frenchwoman Marguerite de la Rocque’s marooning on a Canadian island is one of romance and tragedy.
Little is known of de la Rocque’s life prior to 1542, when she joined a relative, the adventurer Jean-François de la Rocque de Roberval, on his journey to the New World. En route to Canada, Roberval learned that de la Rocque had taken a young man on the ship as her lover. Incensed by the couple’s actions, the Protestant Roberval left them with de la Rocque’s servant on the Isle of Demons, off the coast of Newfoundland.
While in exile, de la Rocque gave birth to a child. At some point afterward, both of her adult companions died, as did the child. Now entirely alone, de la Rocque survived by hunting wild animals with firearms given to the castaways by Roberval’s departing crew.
One of the main historical accounts of de la Rocque’s trials is the Hemptaméron, a collection of short stories by French noblewoman Marguerite de Navarre. The text, which was published posthumously in 1558, suggests that de la Rocque “passed the time in reading, contemplation, prayers and orisons, having a cheerful and contented spirit in a body emaciated and half dead.”
De la Rocque was eventually rescued by passing fishermen. She returned to France, where she became a schoolmistress. The date of her death is unknown, and whether Roberval faced any punishment for deserting her is unclear. He was assassinated in 1560 amid rising tensions between France’s Protestant Huguenots and Catholics.
Philip Ashton
Philip Ashton was near death when he was finally rescued in June 1724 after 16 months of seclusion on an island just off Honduras. It wasn’t the first time the young man from Massachusetts had defied death in recent years.
Ashton was fishing near Nova Scotia in June 1722 when pirates led by Edward Low (better known as Ned Low) attacked his boat. Ashton flatly refused to join up, so the pirates kept him captive as they made their way across the Atlantic, attacking ships near Brazil and the coast of Africa.
When the pirates stopped to collect fresh water off Honduras in March 1723, Ashton managed to secure himself a spot on a rowboat headed to shore. Setting foot on land for the first time since his capture, Ashton escaped the pirates’ clutches by hiding in the woods. But he had no food or equipment to aid his survival. Despite finding fruit and raw turtle eggs to eat, Ashton started to waste away.
In November 1723, an Englishman on the run from the Spanish canoed to the island, where he encountered Ashton. Although the stranger disappeared after venturing out on a hunting trip, he left behind some supplies, including a knife, tobacco and flint, which enabled Ashton to hunt animals and cook meat.
Ashton still had to contend with a fever, the island’s intense heat, and threats from wild animals such as snakes and mosquitoes. He also endured constant hunger and fear of an attack by the Spanish. Finally, in June 1724, a British ship docked at the island and saved Ashton.
Describing the moment he was finally rescued in a 1726 book about his escapades, Ashton said the sailor who found him “started back, frighted to see such a poor, ragged, lean, wan, forlorn, wild, miserable object so near him, but upon recovering himself, he came and took me by the hand, and we fell to embracing one another, he with surprise and wonder, I with a sort of ecstasy of joy.”
After his rescue, Ashton returned to his home state, where he died in 1746.
Ada Blackjack
Although popular culture tends to associate castaways with tropical islands, Ada Blackjack spent two years stuck on the freezing Wrangel Island, above the Arctic Circle.
In 1921, the young Iñupiat woman set off on a two-year expedition from Alaska to Wrangel Island. She was supposed to work as a seamstress, repairing the clothes of the four men she was accompanying on the journey. Although the first year passed without issue, the situation turned dire after the animals the group relied on for food disappeared, and the ship hired to pick them up didn’t arrive. When the expedition’s leader fell ill, the other three men set out for Siberia on foot in search of help. None returned.
Blackjack was left to care for the captain, who died on June 23, 1923. Desperate to be reunited with her son, Bennett, whom she’d placed in an orphanage while she sought work to pay for his tuberculosis treatment, Blackjack survived by fighting off polar bears, catching foxes and shooting birds. She was rescued by a schooner sent to look for the missing expeditioners in August 1923. Upon meeting the rescuers, Blackjack reportedly told them, “There is nobody here but me. I am all alone.”
While the press pleaded to hear every detail of Blackjack’s story, praising her as a female Robinson Crusoe, the lone survivor of the expedition avoided the attention. Instead, she took Bennett to Seattle to undergo medical treatment. Blackjack died in Palmer, Alaska, in 1983, at age 85.
Tongan castaways
In 1966, a real-life parallel to William Golding’s 1954 novel, Lord of the Flies, captivated the world. In June 1965, six teenage boys had run away from their boarding school in the Polynesian nation of Tonga, stolen a boat and set sail for Fiji. On the night of the group’s departure, however, a storm destroyed the rope they’d used to anchor the vessel, as well as its sail and rudder. Over the next eight days, the boys drifted some 100 miles south. Upon spotting the deserted island of ‘Ata, they abandoned their sinking ship and swam to land.
At first, the teens survived on fish, coconuts and birds. Then they discovered traces of the island’s previous inhabitants, who’d been kidnapped and sold into slavery in 1863. These individuals had planted taro and bananas and raised chickens whose descendants still wandered the area a century later.
Did you know? “Blackbirders” in the Pacific Islands
- In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, slave traders forced tens of thousands of Pacific Islanders to work on cotton and sugar plantations in Fiji and Australia. In some cases, the slave traders kidnapped their victims outright; in others, they employed coercive tactics to lure the islanders into slavery.
- The onetime residents of ‘Ata were victims of this practice, which was known as “blackbirding” because of the slave traders’ dark clothing and late-night raids.
The boys built a makeshift house and “started organizing everything in a roster: how to keep the fire, how to say our prayers, along with taking care of the banana palms,” recalled Sione Filipe Totau, one of the six boys, in a 2021 interview with Vice. Unlike the characters in Lord of the Flies, Totau added, “We all worked together as though we’d live on the island for a long time.”
Speaking with the Australian Broadcasting Company in 2020, Tongan storyteller Meleika Gesa-Fatafehi attributed the boys’ survival to their Tongan upbringing. “When we find other Tongans, we stick together,” she said. “That is very much in our value system, and it’s very different to how those fictional boys would have been raised.”
In September 1966, Australian fisherman Peter Warner noticed smoke from a fire while sailing past ‘Ata, which he knew to be uninhabited. He sailed closer to the island, enabling the castaways to spot his boat. One of the boys swam out and explained the situation. When Warner radioed in the teens’ names, the astonished operator replied, “These boys had been given up for dead. Funerals have been held.”
After a huge celebration to mark the boys’ return, Warner hired all six to work on his lobster boat. He remained especially close to Totau, who viewed him as a father figure.
Joseph Rangel
The most recent entry on this list dates to the fall of 2000, when 51-year-old Joseph Rangel and 50-year-old Lorenzo Madrid, both California residents and lifelong friends, joined 24-year-old guide Jose Luis Ramos Garcia on a weeklong fishing trip in the Sea of Cortez. They were initially part of a larger group of 12 people, but one day, Garcia took the two men on a separate excursion in a smaller boat. When the 22-foot-long skiff encountered heavy winds, the trio decided to dock at an island off the coast of Baja California, Mexico.
The men made driftwood oars to row themselves to the mainland, but the winds pushed them back to the island before ultimately wrecking the boat. On one occasion, Garcia attempted to swim some 30 miles to safety but turned back after seeing a shark, the Los Angeles Times reported in 2000.
The trio’s food options were limited to crabs, sea snails and sea cucumbers. As time passed, Madrid began to weaken. Eleven days into the ordeal, he died, apparently of dehydration and exposure. Rescuers found the two surviving men less than 48 hours later. When Rangel returned to shore, he criticized the organizers of the trip, suggesting that the skiff lacked adequate safety measures. “A simple radio would have taken care of it, simple safety equipment and a plan if something went wrong,” Rangel told the Associated Press.

A Stunning Stretch of California’s Rugged Coastline Is Now Open to the Public for the First Time in a Century
Privately owned until 2015, the 547-acre Estero Americano Coast Preserve is welcoming hikers, birdwatchers, wildflower lovers and other outdoor adventurers
Hikers and nature lovers have a new stretch of California’s stunning coastline to explore. The Estero Americano Coast Preserve is now open, offering public access to a 547-acre swath of Marin and Sonoma counties for the first time in a century.
The windswept landscape was a privately owned ranch for decades. But in 2015, the owner agreed to sell the $3.8 million property to the nonprofit Wildlands Conservancy, which had support and funding from several public and private groups. The coalition included the State Coastal Conservancy, Sonoma County Ag + Open Space, the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, the Sonoma Land Trust and individual donors.
Since then, the Wildlands Conservancy team has been hard at work building trails, securing permits, restoring habitats, figuring out parking and making other preparations to open the land to the public.
In November, after a successful trial period, the nonprofit fully opened the preserve, which is situated south of Bodega Bay and west of Valley Ford. It’s now accessible from sunrise to sunset seven days a week, giving outdoor adventurers a rare chance to explore a nearly untouched North Coast landscape for free.
“Our team is very excited that the public is finally able to access this remarkable part of the Sonoma Coast,” Luke Farmer, the Sonoma Coast regional director for the Wildlands Conservancy, tells SFGATE’s Sam Mauhay-Moore.
Quick facts: Wildlife and nature at the Estero Americano Coast Preserve
- The preserve is a vital habitat for numerous creatures, including the threatened central California coast steelhead, the endangered tidewater goby and the threatened California red-legged frog.
- The landscape is “ecologically rich” and protects tidal marshes, eelgrass beds, mudflats and open waters, per the Wildlands Conservancy.
Visitors enter the preserve on foot via the gate off the Shorttail Gulch Trailhead, which is managed by Sonoma County Regional Parks. The preserve is open for hiking, picnicking, walking dogs on leashes, birdwatching and seasonal whale watching.
It’s also an ideal destination for enjoying wildflowers in the spring, when colorful irises and poppies bloom across the hilly, coastal prairie. “I’ve been doing this work for 30 years, and I’ve never seen anything like it,” Misti Arias, general manager of the Sonoma County Ag + Open Space district, tells the San Francisco Chronicle’s Gregory Thomas.
Cycling, horseback riding and camping are not allowed. Restrooms are available, but the site does not have any drinking water.
So far, crews have developed a network of roughly five miles of trails, including a mellow 1.6-mile route that provides easy access to a stretch of beach nestled below some bluffs. Another 1.9-mile trek leads up to the preserve’s highest point, where visitors can soak up expansive views of the Pacific Ocean and surrounding landscape. On clear days, the views extend south to Point Reyes National Seashore and west to the Farallon Islands, reports Active NorCal.
In the future, the conservancy hopes to establish an official pullout for kayakers exploring the Estero Americano Estuary. But in the meantime, paddlers are still welcome to haul their vessels onto the beach and take a break, per the Chronicle.

Astronomers Discover a Mysterious Bar-Shaped Cloud of Iron Within the Iconic Ring Nebula
Humans have been eyeing the colorful Ring Nebula for nearly 250 years, but testing out a new telescope tool led to the perplexing finding
A famous nebula is revealing new secrets even after being observed for almost 250 years.
The Ring Nebula—a glowing gas cloud that looks like a series of colorful rings—has a strange bar-shaped clump of iron atoms within it, data from a new telescope instrument suggests. Researchers describe the discovery in a paper published on January 16 in the journal Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society.
“It is exciting to see that even a very familiar object—much studied over many decades—can throw up a new surprise when observed in a new way,” study co-author Roger Wesson, an astronomer at Cardiff University in Wales, tells Reuters’ Will Dunham.
While not visible with the naked eye, the Ring Nebula, also called Messier 57 or NGC 6720, resides about 2,500 light-years from Earth and can be easily spotted within the constellation Lyra with binoculars or a backyard telescope. French astronomer Charles Messier identified the football-shaped gas cloud in 1779.
Fun fact: Discovery mix-up
For hundreds of years, many people credited the French astronomer Antoine Darquier de Pellepoix with the discovery of the Ring Nebula. But scientific sleuths recently figured out that Messier was actually the first person known to document it.
The celestial object formed a few thousand years ago when a dying star expelled its external layers, and the colors come from different chemical elements. In the Hubble Space Telescope’s images of the Ring Nebula, dark blue represents helium, light blue represents hydrogen and oxygen, and red represents nitrogen and sulfur.
Wesson and his colleagues looked at the famous object in 2023 while testing a new instrument on the William Herschel Telescope in Spain. With the WHT Enhanced Area Velocity Explorer (WEAVE) tool, the researchers could see visible light separated into different wavelengths across the entire face of the nebula. “By obtaining a spectrum continuously across the whole nebula, we can create images of the nebula at any wavelength and determine its chemical composition at any position,” Wesson says in a statement.
“When we processed the data and scrolled through the images, one thing popped out as clear as anything—this previously unknown ‘bar’ of … iron atoms in the middle of the familiar and iconic ring,” he adds.
The bar is quite long, stretching across a length about 500 times the distance of Pluto’s orbit around the sun, and fitting snugly inside the nebula’s innermost layer, per the statement. The researchers estimate that the iron atoms have a cumulative mass comparable to that of Mars.
Moreover, it’s “weird” that the iron cloud doesn’t appear to host any of the chemical elements found elsewhere in the nebula, study co-author Janet Drew, an astrophysicist at University College London, tells Reuters.
The research team currently has two hypotheses for how the iron bar arose. It may represent a previously unknown aspect of how a dying star expels its layers, or it might be the remnants of a rocky planet that got vaporized during the layer-shedding process. More work is needed to figure out the bar’s origins, and Wesson hopes to find other examples of iron clumps within nebulas, which he doubts is a one-of-a-kind occurrance in the Ring Nebula, per the statement.
“We look forward to getting more data to follow up on this discovery, to try to unravel this new problem and work out where the iron bar has come from,” Wesson tells Reuters.

These Are the Top Ten Most Anticipated Museums Opening Around the World in 2026
New institutions dedicated to digital art, exploration, hip-hop, conservation and more are expected to welcome visitors this year
Visitors to the Smithsonian Institution have a lot to look forward to in 2026. The National Air and Space Museum will complete its multiyear renovation with the reopening of its remaining galleries on July 1, the National Museum of African American History and Culture marks its 10th anniversary with a block-party bash in September and the Hirshhorn’s revitalized Sculpture Garden reopens in October.
America commemorates its 250th birthday this year, and the Smithsonian museums are sharing in the semiquincentennial celebration with a range of exhibitions, festivities and reopenings. The historic carousel on the National Mall is scheduled to reopen to the public in time for D.C.’s Fourth of July anniversary party, and the Smithsonian Castle will pause its first major renovation in more than 50 years to reopen to the public from Memorial Day weekend through Labor Day. Along with a visitor’s center, café and souvenir shop, the Castle will feature a special exhibition, “American Aspirations,” showcasing artifacts reflecting America's journey, including abolitionist Harriet Tubman's hymnal. Another exhibition, “In Pursuit of Life, Liberty & Happiness,” opens at the National Museum of American History on May 14 and highlights 250 objects that explore the ideals of the Declaration of Independence, such as the desk Thomas Jefferson used to write the Declaration of Independence and the oldest surviving American fighting ship. This year will also see the expansion of the annual Smithsonian Folklife Festival. Titled “Of the People: The Smithsonian Festival of Festivals,” this larger, multisite experience aims to explore festivals as a powerful tool of civic engagement and cultural exchange.
Around the globe, a range of new museums dedicated to everything from Aboriginal Australian people to hip-hop culture are scheduled to open. The world’s first museum of A.I. digital arts, Dataland in Los Angeles, is expected to welcome public visitors, as is the United Arab Emirates' Guggenheim Abu Dhabi, an enormous repository of modern and contemporary art. The opening of London’s Museum of Shakespeare has been delayed indefinitely, though—fingers crossed—it could happen this year.
Whether you’re looking to take on the role of a National Geographic explorer or marvel at a Picasso painting up-close in a converted Art Deco garage, these 10 museums will open new ways to experience, appreciate and understand the world around us.
The Lucas Museum of Narrative Art; Los Angeles
Nearly a decade in the making, the Lucas Museum of Narrative Art is finally set to open in L.A.’s Exposition Park on September 22. This brainchild of American filmmaker George Lucas and American businesswoman Mellody Hobson celebrates the universal language of visual storytelling and its ability to connect people. Situated on an 11-acre campus, the five-story, 300,000-square-foot building will feature 35 galleries and a permanent collection of over 40,000 works highlighting all forms of narrative art, including murals, sculpture, photography, posters, illustrations, animation cels and even magic-lantern slides (painted or photographed images on glass plates). Along with images by beloved illustrators like Norman Rockwell and Beatrix Potter, original comic strips by cartoonists such as Charles Schulz and Jack Kirby, and iconic works by painter Frida Kahlo and photographer Dorothea Lange, the museum will also showcase cinematic artifacts, including lightsabers and original costumes from Lucas’ own Star Wars universe. Additional amenities include two on-site theaters, a restaurant and a retail store.
National Geographic Museum of Exploration; Washington, D.C.
Since 1888, the National Geographic Society has illuminated the wonders of our world through travel, science, education and storytelling. This summer, the new National Geographic Museum of Exploration will help bring these wonders to life, using cutting-edge technology, visual journeys and interactive experiences. Located at the Society's headquarters in D.C., the over-100,000-square-foot, sustainably built space will feature a “walking dark ride” that transports visitors to remote fieldwork expeditions and an interactive, large-scale digital installation of National Geographic’s magazine covers, beginning with its first issue in 1888. Visitors will be able to watch National Geographic films and exploration stories in an immersive, 400-seat theater and enjoy a nighttime courtyard experience that recreates six global ecosystems through life-size animal sculptures, touchable prints and audioscapes. Guests enter the museum through an 11-foot-tall yellow border that mimics the magazine’s iconic cover frame.
The museum’s inaugural exhibit, “Photo Ark: Animals of Earth,” uses large-scale projections, touch interactives and images from the National Geographic Photo Ark, created and led by National Geographic Explorer Joel Sartore, to inspire protection of the world’s at-risk species.
UBS Digital Art Museum; Hamburg, Germany
Scheduled to open in the spring, the UBS Digital Art Museum will be Europe’s largest institution dedicated to digital and immersive art. Visitors will be treated to a fully integrated art experience, with approximately 70,000 square feet of exhibition space, soaring 39-foot-high ceilings and a permanent, multisensory work by international digital artist collective teamLab that occupies the entire museum. The exhibit, “teamLab Borderless,” consists of large-scale projections, interactive environments and everchanging narratives that forgo fixed boundaries and move throughout rooms, responding to each person’s movement, touch and physical presence. The museum is located within Hamburg’s HafenCity district, a massive waterfront development area known for its experimental architecture.
London Museum; London
The former Museum of London closed in December 2022 to reinvent itself as the soon-to-open London Museum. With easy access to public transit and significantly more space (290,000 square feet—roughly 6.6 acres—up from 183,000 square feet), this new iteration is scheduled to open in late 2026 in the city’s former Smithfield Market district. The London Museum aims to tell the story of Londoners—such as Winifred Herbert, who served as a cook during World War II, and fashion designer Mary Quant—across 450,000 years, and will be one of the largest urban history collections in the world. It holds more than six million objects documenting the city’s history, including Roman mosaics, medieval armor, Victorian-era ironwork and street artist Banksy’s Piranhas, a painted box that appeared on a central London street in 2024. A unique feature of the new space will be a train line that allows passengers to peek inside the galleries as it passes.
The museum’s permanent galleries will occupy Smithfield’s abandoned Victorian General Market. The adjacent 1960s Poultry Market, opening in 2028, will house temporary exhibitions, collection stores and a learning center. The area has significant history: Smithfield once served as a Roman cemetery and hosted the boisterous Bartholomew Fair. It also played a prominent role in the novels of Londoner Charles Dickens, including Oliver Twist and Great Expectations.
MoN Takanawa: The Museum of Narratives; Tokyo
Tokyo’s MoN Takanawa: The Museum of Narratives blends traditional Japanese culture with cutting-edge technology. When it opens in March, this multilevel (six stories above ground, three below), experimental museum will combine traditional arts (like Kabuki) and food with manga, music and science, connecting the past with the future. New themes will be presented twice annually, beginning with the inaugural “Life as Culture,” which explores how everyday actions such as working, eating and resting create and sustain civilization.
The museum offers a unique mix of Japanese and futuristic aesthetics. Along with a restaurant and café, MoN Takanawa also includes an underground theater immersed in digital LED panels and an experiential area for workshops. There’s a traditional tatami mat space for relaxing, an on-site library and three open-air terraces, including one where visitors can soak tired feet.
Dr. Jane's Dream: The Goodall Centre of Hope; Arusha, Tanzania
Jane Goodall died in October 2025, but the dreams of the groundbreaking English primatologist and environmental activist live on in Tanzania. Goodall spent her life connecting with the natural world, and Dr. Jane's Dream: The Goodall Centre of Hope inspires visitors to do the same. The space is scheduled to open in late October next to the Arusha Cultural Heritage Center, about 50 miles from Moshi, Mount Kilimanjaro’s gateway town. Brought together by a team of Disney alumni and African artists, Dr. Jane’s Dream will embody the scientist’s message of active hope through interactive exhibits, community-led conservation initiatives and screenings at an on-site theater. Visitors can listen to Goodall’s English translations of chimp cries at a stand-alone kiosk, see elaborately carved and painted tree trunks created by local Makonde artists and even “fish” for food in a recreated termite mound using small probes, similar to how chimpanzees did in Goodall’s groundbreaking 1960 discovery.
Larrakia Cultural Centre; Northern Territory, Australia
Aboriginal Australian people have one of the oldest continuous living cultures on the planet. Australia’s Larrakia Cultural Centre pays homage to the Larrakia people— traditional owners of the land and sea that today comprise the country’s Greater Darwin Region, whose history and stories date back tens of thousands of years. At this multilevel space overlooking Darwin Harbor, visitors will be able to participate in hands-on painting and weaving workshops, observe Aboriginal music performances and learn the Larrakia language. The museum will display plenty of Larrakia treasures in its extensive exhibit space. These include sacred artifacts, such as glass spearheads and personal ornaments, that have been repatriated from international and Australian institutions.
The building features a bird-shaped roof that evokes a Larrakia ancestral being. Inside, there will be a restaurant showcasing local flavors, art studios and a retail shop, while outdoor areas will brim with native landscaping, an amphitheater with a sand performance area, and a saltwater ceremonial pond. It’s scheduled to open in October.
The Hip Hop Museum; Bronx, New York
The musical genre known as hip-hop came into the world in the 1970s. Known for its stylized rhythmic sounds, turntables and rapping, hip-hop became a cultural movement, influencing everything from fashion to technology. New York’s Hip Hop Museum, opening along the Harlem River waterfront this autumn, celebrates it all.
Situated just a couple of miles south of “the birthplace of hip-hop,” 1520 Sedgwick Avenue in the Bronx, the 55,000-square-foot museum will be home to 30,000 objects highlighting how hip-hop has impacted the world, making its way to concert arenas and influencing dance, politics, education and more.
Floor-to-ceiling displays will include items previously showcased at the museum’s temporary location in the Bronx Terminal Market, such as Dapper Dan custom-made jackets and Rappin’ Max Robot, the first hip-hop comic book. Artist and designer Eric Orr created the four-issue series in 1986 with assistance from pop artist Keith Haring.
Center of Islamic Civilization; Tashkent, Uzbekistan
Although Uzbekistan is officially a secular state, Islam remains a key part of its culture and identity. Opening in March, the Center of Islamic Civilization in Tashkent will highlight the country’s contributions to Islam and serve as a global hub for studying and promoting the religion’s history, science and spiritual heritage. The three-story structure will feature more than 150,000 square feet of exhibit space and eight galleries showcasing Uzbekistan's Islamic heritage. They will include a collection of 114 Quranic manuscripts created by renowned rulers and calligraphers through the ages and a seventh-century Othman Quran (one of the oldest in the world). The center will also have interactive educational zones that utilize modern tech; for example, a series of “living portraits” of historical thinkers and scientists will answer visitors’ questions using artificial intelligence. The institution touts a research center devoted to the study and preservation of Islam, labs for restoring ancient manuscripts and a 460-seat conference hall.
The architecture of the center blends Timurid-era Central Asian traditions (including intricate tilework and a 213-foot-tall blue dome) with modern design, putting Islam’s vast heritage on full display.
The Kanal-Centre Pompidou; Brussels, Belgium
Brussels' first museum dedicated to modern and contemporary art is scheduled to open November 28. The Kanal-Centre Pompidou will be one of Europe’s largest museums, with 430,000 square feet of space. This cultural hub is part of the landmark Centre Pompidou in Paris and emphasizes 21st-century Belgian art along with works from the main museum’s expansive collection. Visitors will be able to study pieces by pioneer of abstract art Wassily Kandinsky and Cubist Pablo Picasso, marvel at video installations such as artist Anthony McCall's light sculptures, and explore one of pop artist Roy Lichtenstein’s porcelain enamel-on-steel prints. Along with both permanent and temporary exhibitions, the museum will feature live music, dance and other performing arts, a library and a bakery. It’s all housed within Brussels’ former Citroën garage, an Art Deco industrial space that has been transformed and repurposed.

Archaeologists Say They’ve Detected the Largest Stand-Alone Ancient Roman Villa Ever Unearthed in Wales
The mansion’s foundations and floors are likely well-preserved, according to geophysical surveys. The discovery provides new insights into the Roman occupation in the region
Using ground-penetrating radar, researchers in south Wales have uncovered the foundations of an ancient Roman villa. The discovery illuminates the history of Roman occupation in the region, suggesting that it was more than just a military outpost for the empire.
The villa could be the largest known stand-alone structure of its kind to be found in Wales. It was discovered in Margam Country Park, located in the county of Neath Port Talbot, during geophysical surveys by the local company Terradat. The surveys were commissioned by the ArchaeoMargam project, a collaboration between nearby Swansea University’s Center for Heritage Research and Training, Neath Port Talbot Council and Margam Abbey Church.
The project aimed to uncover Margam’s pre-industrial heritage—and according to a statement from Swansea University, “the team struck gold.”
The massive villa’s foundations, located roughly three feet below the surface, stretch about 141 feet long, Langlands tells BBC News’ Steffan Messenger. The “really impressive and prestigious” structure appears to have six main front rooms and two halls leading to eight rear rooms.
Southeast of the mansion is the footprint of another structure, which may have been a meeting hall or agricultural storage facility. The buildings appear to have been surrounded by a defensive enclosure, which covered an area of more than 25,000 square feet.
“Almost certainly you’ve got a major local dignitary making themselves at home here,” Langlands explains to BBC News. “This would have been quite a busy place—the center of a big agricultural estate and lots of people coming and going.”
After the Romans invaded Britain in 43 C.E., they built structures such as military forts, roads, walls and baths. In Wales, most Roman ruins were built for the army, like the large Roman fortress and bath complex in nearby Caerleon. Stately Roman homes aren’t commonly found in Wales. However, the newly discovered foundations remind Langlands of sites found in places like Gloucestershire, Somerset and Dorset.
Quick fact: How long did the Romans control Britain?
The emperor Claudius invaded Britain in 43 C.E., and the Romans remained in power until around 410 C.E.
The newly discovered villa could demonstrate that Wales wasn’t just a “kind of liminal borderland,” Langlands says to the New York Times’ Stephen Castle. Instead, it may have been “just as Roman as anywhere else we’ve got in the heartlands of the province of Britannia.”
As the archaeologist explains in the statement, it’s too early to date the Margam villa or determine who built it. However, he tells the Guardian, “I think we’re in the fourth century—it really fits that kind of late Roman flourish that we see in the southwest of Britain.”
Because Margam has been a deer park since at least the Middle Ages, it has not been disturbed by agricultural ploughing. As such, researchers are hoping to find the villa to be well-preserved when they eventually excavate it, and the surveys indicate that much of the villa’s flooring and foundations are intact. The team has optimistically nicknamed the site “the Port Talbot Pompeii,” in reference to the Roman city that was covered in volcanic ash in 79 C.E.
“Wherever you get villas like this, they’re almost certainly surrounded by other edifices of the period,” Langlands says in a video from Swansea University. “We’ve probably got trading centers here. We know we’ve got the Roman roads here. There should be a bathhouse somewhere, and almost certainly there’ll be other small Roman farmsteads.”
Researchers are keeping the exact location of the buried villa a secret to prevent outsiders from illegally digging on the site before the experts. The team shared its findings with the local community at Margam Abbey Church on January 17.
“It’s out of this world,” Margaret Jones, a retired teacher from Port Talbot, tells BBC News. “I’m still a bit shellshocked at the thought that this place where I played, where my children and grandchildren have played—that under our feet was this incredible house.”
